properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 9 January 2011. Nyala (South Darfur): South Sudanese voters wait on the queue before getting access to the Giyada polling center, in Nyala (South Darfur) in the first day of referendum. This polling center has the largest number of registered South Sudanese voters in Darfur (almost 3,.500). In all Darfur, there are around 20,000 registered people (mostly based in the South) and 20 polling centres. Around four million southern Sudanese began to vote in the referendum today to decide whether the region should remain united with the north or secede to establish an independent state. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 12 January 2011. Al Lait (Noth Darfur): Supporters of the unity of all Sudan (and against the independence of South Sudan) demonstrate in front of Alleyet North Center (polling station) in Al Lait city (North Darfur). In this village, located near the border with South Darfur and Southern Kordofan) there are more than 2,000 Southern Sudanese registered for the referendum. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 9 January 2011. Nyala (South Darfur): South Sudan Referendum Comission (SSRC) staff member close a ballot in Giyada polling center, in Nyala (South Darfur) before starting the first day of referendum. This polling center has the largest number of registered South Sudanese voters in Darfur (almost 3,.500). In all Darfur, there are around 20,000 registered people (mostly based in the South) and 20 polling centres. Around four million southern Sudanese began to vote in the referendum today to decide whether the region should remain united with the north or secede to establish an independent state. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 12 January 2011. Al Lait (Noth Darfur): Supporters of the unity of all Sudan (and against the independence of South Sudan) demonstrate in front of Alleyet North Center (polling station) in Al Lait city (North Darfur). In this village, located near the border with South Darfur and Southern Kordofan) there are more than 2,000 Southern Sudanese registered for the referendum. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 9 January 2011. Nyala (South Darfur): Southern Sudanese voters waiting on the queue in Giyada polling center, in Nyala (South Darfur) for the South Sudanese self determination. This polling center has the largest number of registered South Sudanese in Darfur (almost 3,.500). In all Darfur, there are around 20,000 registered people (mostly based in the South) and 20 polling centres. Around four million southern Sudanese began to vote in the referendum today to decide whether the region should remain united with the north or secede to establish an independent state. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 9 January 2011. Nyala (South Darfur): Two South Sudanese voters wait on the queue before getting access to the Giyada polling center, in Nyala (South Darfur) in the first day of referendum. This polling center has the largest number of registered South Sudanese voters in Darfur (almost 3,.500). In all Darfur, there are around 20,000 registered people (mostly based in the South) and 20 polling centres. Around four million southern Sudanese began to vote in the referendum today to decide whether the region should remain united with the north or secede to establish an independent state. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 9 January 2011. Nyala (South Darfur): South Sudanese voters wait on the queue before getting access to the Giyada polling center, in Nyala (South Darfur) in the first day of referendum. This polling center has the largest number of registered South Sudanese voters in Darfur (almost 3,.500). In all Darfur, there are around 20,000 registered people (mostly based in the South) and 20 polling centres. Around four million southern Sudanese began to vote in the referendum today to decide whether the region should remain united with the north or secede to establish an independent state. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 12 January 2011. Al Lait (Noth Darfur): Some Southern Sudanese register their names to vote on the referendum for self determination in Alleyet North Center in Al Lait city (North Darfur). In this village, located near the border with South Darfur and Southern Kordofan) there are more than 2,000 Southern Sudanese registered for the referendum. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 12 January 2011. Al Lait (Noth Darfur): A Southern Sudanese aproaches to vote on the referendum for self determination in Alleyet North Center in Al Lait city (North Darfur). In this village, located near the border with South Darfur and Southern Kordofan) there are more than 2,000 Southern Sudanese registered for the referendum. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 9 January 2011. Nyala (South Darfur): A Southern Sudanese, currently living in Darfur, votes in Giyada polling center, in Nyala (South Darfur) for the South Sudanese self determination. This polling center has the largest number of registered South Sudanese in Darfur (almost 3,.500). In all Darfur, there are around 20,000 registered people (mostly based in the South) and 20 polling centres. Around four million southern Sudanese began to vote in the referendum today to decide whether the region should remain united with the north or secede to establish an independent state. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 9 January 2011. Nyala (South Darfur): A South Sudan Referendum Comission (SSRC) staff member controls de queue to the Giyada polling center, in Nyala (South Darfur) in the first day of referendum. This polling center has the largest number of registered South Sudanese voters in Darfur (almost 3,.500). In all Darfur, there are around 20,000 registered people (mostly based in the South) and 20 polling centres. Around four million southern Sudanese began to vote in the referendum today to decide whether the region should remain united with the north or secede to establish an independent state. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 15 November 2010. El Fasher: A South Sudanese registers his name in El Fasher (North Darfur) and collects his ID voting card for the coming referendum on the self-determination of South Sudan (expected on 9 January). There are 13 registration points in the region for the people from South Sudan currently living in Darfur: 3 in North Darfur, 2 in West Darfur and 8 more in South Darfur. The registration process will take 17 calendar days. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: South Sudan Referendum in Darfur
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: 28 November 2010. El Fasher: Southern Sudanese voters register their names at the only one registration center in El Fasher for the coming referendum of self determination in South Sudan. In Darfur, there are 20 registration centers and more than 5,000 people registered already. The registration process has been extended. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran / UNAMID / www.albertgonzalez.net

properties.title: Kumma
properties.description: risotto al caviale posted a photo: Rock inscription at Kumma, near Semna, northern Sudan, with the Address to the Living formula. Not my photo. On the rear it says, "Felsinschrift von Kumme (Semne-Ost)." See Dunham-Janssen, Semna, 141: RIK no. 12.

properties.title: Community Participates in Development Planning
properties.description: IFRC posted a photo: Sumba Lorie South Sudan 4 July 2011 - community members of all ages participate in planning their development. Photo: IFRC (p-SDN0159) Please visit www.ifrc.org for more information from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

properties.title: Community Members Listen to Red Cross Volunteers
properties.description: IFRC posted a photo: Sumba Lorie South Sudan 4 July 2011 - community members listen to RC volunteers explain how the VCA works. Photo: IFRC (p-SDN0158) Please visit www.ifrc.org for more information from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

properties.title: Children in Sumba Lorie
properties.description: IFRC posted a photo: Sumba Lorie South Sudan 4 July 2011 - children play with catapults by the latrines as the adults discuss the problems of hygiene and sanitation in the village. Photo: IFRC (p-SDN0157) Please visit www.ifrc.org for more information from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

properties.title: Woman and Child Waiting in Line
properties.description: International Foundation for Electoral Systems posted a photo: On the first day of polling, children waited in line with their parents for an historic vote. Many, such as this little girl, were dressed up for what was clearly a special occasion to their parents. Sara Staino/IFES.

properties.title: Countdown to Referendum
properties.description: International Foundation for Electoral Systems posted a photo: Anticipation in advance of the 2011 Referendum is high with billboards and huge digital clocks ticking away the time remaining before the vote. This clock shows that the time to vote has come. Photo by Matthew Parry/IFES

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A student at Zalingei University, West Darfur, protests during a visit of the Doha peace negotiation team, headed by African Union-United Nations Joint Chief Mediator Dijbril Bassolé. As the delegation departed, the protests turned violent, resulting in at least two deaths and several wounded. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: An Egyptian peacekeeper prays beside a fellow soldier’s coffin in Edd al Fursan, South Darfur. The soldier was killed in an ambush by a group of unidentified armed men. In all, two Egyptian peacekeepers were left dead and three injured. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: Members of the Sudanese army in Jawa village, in East Jebel Marra, South Darfur. The area is controlled by Government forces. Most of the population fled due to the clashes between the army and rebel movements. Jebel Marra is one of the most war-torn areas in Darfur, making it difficult for the international community to access. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A woman takes mathematics lessons at the Women’s Center in the internally displaced persons camp at Abu Shouk, North Darfur. About 80 women visit the Center five days a week to study Arabic, mathematics and the Koran. From time to time, they also participate in other activities sponsored by UN Agencies and Non-Governmental Organizations. Women usually attend the classes with their children. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: Children learning the Koran at a camp for refugees from the Central African Republic in Mukhjar, West Darfur. They came to Darfur a few months ago looking for a safe place to live. UNAMID peacekeepers from Thailand patrol the area and interact with the population, providing security. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A woman sheltered outside a small UNAMID military base in Khor Abeche, South Darfur, after clashes drove her from her village in December 2010. Thousands of villagers, seeking protection, settled in makeshift tents and huts beside the mission’s compound for several weeks. The peacekeepers assisted them by providing water and medical aid. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A child abandons Tukumare, North Darfur, after the village was bombed. Fighting in Tabit during the last week of January 2011 affected eight villages, including Tukumare, Kuto, Konjara Tarni and Tangarara, and caused thousands of people to flee the area. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A group of women from Seraf Jedad, West Darfur, meet at the local Women’s Centre. In April 2009, more than 4,000 people returned to the village from the Abuzair camp for internally displaced persons ─.mostly from the Arenga tribe. With the help of UNAMID and the Sudanese Government, they have begun to rebuild the school, install five new water hand pumps, resume agriculture activities, reopen the market and clinic, and build the new Women’s Centre. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A child in Zam Zam camp for internally displaced persons, North Darfur, checks his relatives’ names on the voters list for the presidential election, marking the first election in 24 years with multiple political parties. With 68 per cent of the ballots, Omar al Bashir, President of the Sudan since 1989, was declared the winner. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A South African peacekeeper patrols in an armoured personal carrier in Kutum, North Darfur. Nearly 700 South African peacekeepers are posted in North Darfur. In all, about 18,000 soldiers from 40 different countries account for the mission’s military contingent. UNAMID is currently the largest peacekeeping mission in the world and one of the largest in United Nations history. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: Children at the local school in Sullu, West Darfur, with three volunteers teaching them. There are about 75 students in attendance, some of whom arrived recently from the Kalma camp for displaced persons, South Darfur. The new arrivals settle in the village by making shelters out of branches and plastic sheeting. The local community helps by providing health assistance and education to the children. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: IFRC Delegate Lena Leipe Listens to Community
properties.description: IFRC posted a photo: Sumba Lorie South Sudan 4 July 2011 - IFRC organisational development delegate, Lena Leipe, listens to the communities suggestions for development. Photo: IFRC (p-SDN0160) Please visit www.ifrc.org for more information from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

properties.title: New Mothers in Sumba Lorie
properties.description: IFRC posted a photo: Sumba Lorie South Sudan 4 July 2011 - new mothers have a specific interest in developing their community to improve infant health. Photo: IFRC (p-SDN0161) Please visit www.ifrc.org for more information from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A child displays bullets collected from the ground in Rounyn, a village located north of Shangil Tobaya, North Darfur. Due to the fighting between the Government and the armed movements, most of the population in Rounyn recently fled to camps for displaced persons. The fewer than 100 households ─ comprised mostly of farmers and children ─ still remaining live in fear of new attacks. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A child in Buru, West Darfur, with a severe eye infection is attended to by UNAMID peacekeepers. Most children have serious diseases and infections due to the lack of health care in the village - the nearest clinic is 30 km away. Due to the difficulties in accessing Buru, UN peacekeepers are only able to visit on rare occasions. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A family of displaced persons in Kalma camp, South Darfur, settles in a truck before departing to their native village in West Darfur. As part of the first Government-run operation, after months of preparations, hundreds of Kalma residents began to return home with UN assistance. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: Policewomen from Rwanda arrive at El Fasher airport to begin their work with UNAMID. More than 5,000 police officers from 40 countries are currently deployed in Darfur, Sudan. Among them, approximately 600 are women. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A woman, originally from Southern Sudan, waits on line at a polling station in Nyala, South Darfur (Darfur is located in Northern Sudan.) Approximately 20,000 people from Southern Sudan were registered in 20 polling centres in Darfur to participate in the January referendum concerning self-determination for Southern Sudan. Southerners voted overwhelmingly for independence. The ballot was the culmination of the 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement that ended two decades of civil war between Sudan’s north and south and left some two million people dead and 4 million displaced, some of whom fled north to Darfur. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: A doctor examines a young girl in Kalma camp for displaced persons in Nyala, South Darfur, before she returns to her village in West Darfur. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close": Photo Exhibition at the UN Headquarters
properties.description: Albert Gonzalez Farran posted a photo: Residents of Abu Nas, North Darfur, a village frequently looted by militias. The more than 2,000 people living in the area routinely flee to the mountains for safety. UN Agencies visit regularly to assist the population, but security is often a real concern. Photo by Albert Gonzalez Farran - www.albertgonzalez.net - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: After fleeing their village of Tabara, North Darfur, a woman with her two children takes refuge in a temporary shelter in Tawilla, North Darfur. On 2 September 2010, a group of unidentified armed men opened fire in the busy marketplace of Tabara, killing dozens of villagers. More than 700 households fled to Tawilla, where a UNAMID base is located. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A woman, originally from Southern Sudan, waits on line at a polling station in Nyala, South Darfur (Darfur is located in Northern Sudan.) Approximately 20,000 people from Southern Sudan were registered in 20 polling centres in Darfur to participate in the January referendum concerning self-determination for Southern Sudan. Southerners voted overwhelmingly for independence. The ballot was the culmination of the 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement that ended two decades of civil war between Sudan’s north and south and left some two million people dead and 4 million displaced, some of whom fled north to Darfur. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A sheik (community leader) of Mornei camp for internally displaced persons, North Darfur, who lost family members in recent clashes, cries during a meeting with UNAMID Joint Special Representative Ibrahim Gambari. People in Mornei suffer because of food shortages, the deterioration of the security situation and the lack of health services. Those displaced describe the living conditions in the camp as difficult because they are frequently threatened and robbed by armed men. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: An Egyptian peacekeeper prays beside a fellow soldier’s coffin in Edd al Fursan, South Darfur. The soldier was killed in an ambush by a group of unidentified armed men. In all, two Egyptian peacekeepers were left dead and three injured. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A group of women from Seraf Jedad, West Darfur, meet at the local Women’s Centre. With the help of UNAMID and the Sudanese Government, they have begun to rebuild the school, install five new water hand pumps, resume agriculture activities, reopen the market and clinic, and build the new Women’s Centre. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A doctor examines a young girl in Kalma camp for displaced persons in Nyala, South Darfur, before she returns to her village in West Darfur. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

The new arrivals settle in the village by making shelters out of branches and plastic sheeting. The local community helps by providing health assistance and education to the children. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: Separation Forum 3
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Atem and Muneer sit at Tirhas, a cafe named after its Ethiopian proprietor, and dream about the upcoming referendum on separation of South Sudan from the North. This series of photos were taken a month before the January 2011 referendum. Photo Credit: Louis

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: Residents of Abu Nas, North Darfur, a village frequently looted by militias. The more than 2,000 people living in the area routinely flee to the mountains for safety. UN Agencies visit regularly to assist the population, but security is often a real concern. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: Coffee break in Juba
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Two lovely women wearing beautiful tobes, sitting in a cafe in Juba, Sudan. These women were taking a break from filming a video about HIV/AIDS prevention. Photo credit: Majok Maluk Atem

properties.title: Separation Forum 1
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Atem and Muneer sit at Tirhas, a cafe named after its Ethiopian proprietor, and dream about the upcoming referendum on separation of South Sudan from the North. This series of photos were taken a month before the January 2011 referendum. Photo Credit: Louis

properties.title: Welcome South Sudan!
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Boy holding a sign from the Sudan Liberation Army welcoming independence to South Sudan. Juba, Sudan, July 9, 2011. Photo Credit: Nicki Kindersley

properties.title: Independent fashions for independence day
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Crowds gather in Juba on July 9, 2011 to celebrate South Sudan's inaugural day as an independent state. Dissonant ideas mingle as do dissonant fashions! Photo Credit: Nicki Kindersley

properties.title: South Sudan independence
properties.description: raccoflickr posted a photo: Al Jazeera English: Live Stream

properties.title: DTN News - BIRTH OF A NATION NEWS: From Decades of Strife And Conflict, Africa's Newest Nation Is Born
properties.description: DTN News posted a photo: (NSI News Source Info) TORONTO, Canada - July 8, 2011: The boundaries on Africa's maps will once again be re-drawn, this time as the newest nation in the world readies itself for full independence from Sudan on Saturday. After a decade of civil war with Khartoum and an uneasy five year cease-fire, celebrations marking the formation of the new state are set to get underway in the South Sudanese capital of Juba on Saturday. This new nation will be slightly smaller than the state of Texas in terms of size.defense-technologynews.blogspot.com/2011/07/dtn-news-birt...

properties.title: Study Break in Juba, Sudan
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Some students taking a study break at a cafe in Juba, Sudan. Winter 2011. Photo Credit: Majok Maluk Atem.

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A student at Zalingei University, West Darfur, protests during a visit of the Doha peace negotiation team, headed by African Union-United Nations Joint Chief Mediator Dijbril Bassolé. As the delegation departed, the protests turned violent, resulting in at least two deaths and several wounded. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A South African peacekeeper patrols in an armoured personal carrier in Kutum, North Darfur. Nearly 700 South African peacekeepers are posted in North Darfur. In all, about 18,000 soldiers from 40 different countries account for the mission’s military contingent. UNAMID is currently the largest peacekeeping mission in the world and one of the largest in United Nations history. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A child displays bullets collected from the ground in Rounyn, a village located north of Shangil Tobaya, North Darfur. Due to the fighting between the Government and the armed movements, most of the population in Rounyn recently fled to camps for displaced persons. The fewer than 100 households ─ comprised mostly of farmers and children ─ still remaining live in fear of new attacks. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: Members of the Sudanese army in Jawa village, in East Jebel Marra, South Darfur. The area is controlled by Government forces. Most of the population fled due to the clashes between the army and rebel movements. Jebel Marra is one of the most war-torn areas in Darfur, making it difficult for the international community to access. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A woman takes mathematics lessons at the Women’s Center in the internally displaced persons camp at Abu Shouk, North Darfur. About 80 women visit the Center five days a week to study Arabic, mathematics and the Koran. From time to time, they also participate in other activities sponsored by UN Agencies and Non-Governmental Organizations. Women usually attend the classes with their children. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A child in Zam Zam camp for internally displaced persons, North Darfur, checks his relatives’ names on the voters list for the presidential election, marking the first election in 24 years with multiple political parties. With 68 per cent of the ballots, Omar al Bashir, President of the Sudan since 1989, was declared the winner. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: Separation Forum 2
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Atem and Muneer sit at Tirhas, a cafe named after its Ethiopian proprietor, and dream about the upcoming referendum on separation of South Sudan from the North. This series of photos was taken a month before the January 2011 referendum. Photo Credit: Louis

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A child abandons Tukumare, North Darfur, after the village was bombed. Fighting in Tabit during the last week of January 2011 affected eight villages, including Tukumare, Kuto, Konjara Tarni and Tangarara, and caused thousands of people to flee the area. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: Policewomen from Rwanda arrive at El Fasher airport to begin their work with UNAMID. More than 5,000 police officers from 40 countries are currently deployed in Darfur, Sudan. Among them, approximately 600 are women. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: "Darfur Up Close"- photo exhibition at the UN headquarters
properties.description: UNAMID Photo posted a photo: A family of displaced persons in Kalma camp, South Darfur, settles in a truck before departing to their native village in West Darfur. As part of the first Government-run operation, after months of preparations, hundreds of Kalma residents began to return home with UN assistance. © Albert Gonzalez Farran - UNAMID

properties.title: #welcome193 Campaign Video
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: In July 2011, Juba Media Collective collaborated with the folks of the #welcome193 social media campaign to conduct interviews with folks all over Juba and South Sudan to see what they were thinking as independence grew closer. This short video montage was the first product of this collaboration. #welcome south sudan! See this video at Juba Media Collective's youtube channel here: www.youtube.com/user/JubaMediaCollective?feature=mhee#p/f...

properties.title: Lobur Elikana, interview
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Juba Media Collective interviewed Lobur Elikana, a member of Friendship Drama Group and citizen of South Sudan in the days before independence celebrations of July 2011. See the interview at Juba Media Collective's youtube channel:www.youtube.com/user/JubaMediaCollective?feature=mhee#p/a...

properties.title: Douglas Johnson Present
properties.description: Juba Media Collective posted a photo: Douglas Johnson, researcher, writer and scholar on Sudan, attends one of the independence day celebrations in Juba. Johnson's publications include the books Root Causes of Sudan's Civil Wars and Nuer Prophets Photo Credit: Nicki Kindersley

properties.title: UNHCR News Story: Q&A: Displacement scenarios surrounding South Sudan secession
properties.description: UNHCR posted a photo: Southern Sudanese returning to Unity state in the newly-independent South Sudan. UNHCR / A. Coseac / November 2010Q&A: Displacement scenarios surrounding South Sudan secession GENEVA, July 11 (UNHCR) – As South Sudan became an independent country last weekend, the UN refugee agency joined the international community in welcoming this historic event. However, there are a number of ongoing displacement situations affecting the country. Dominik Bartsch, UNHCR Operations Manager for Chad and Sudan, recently spoke to Geneva-based journalists on the issue.Excerpts from his opening statement: I will briefly touch upon three current displacement scenarios in Sudan. The first one involves the ongoing return of Southerners from the north. The second one is the ongoing new displacements from the protocol areas, notably Abyei and Southern Kordofan. And thirdly, a brief reflection on South Sudan itself and the internal displacement that is occurring there. Starting with the return of the Southerners, more than 1 million Southerners are still residing in the north. Some 300,000 have returned since late October back to the South. We have currently a situation where significant numbers of Southerners are stranded en route because of capacity constraints along the way. There's a group of some 17,000 Southerners who are still waiting in Khartoum to return. They have sold their houses and belongings, and are sitting with their property on street corners waiting for transport to arrive. We are now engaging with partners to try to decongest the situation and help those Southerners move on. In the South, we want to highlight that the region itself currently has a number of conflict hot spots. There are areas in which inter-communal violence is taking place, we have ethnic clashes and we have a number of active military insurgencies in the South. So there are concerns how these hot spots could generate internal displacement and indeed, in a worst-case scenario, how they may also prompt refugees to move across borders.Excerpts from the interview:It seems the citizenship issue has been resolved, with South Sudanese in the north being asked to either move to South Sudan and give up their citizenship, or remain in the north and continue being citizens there. Is there a deadline for them to decide? What has happened with respect to citizenship laws is that South Sudan has passed a new law which in fact is fairly generous and allows for recognition of citizenship for all Southerners. However, in the north, a similar law has not been amended and there is quite some ambiguity around this issue as well as political rhetoric as to which rights will be granted to Southerners including citizenship. So right now there is no clear line. The fact that Southerners would be encouraged by the north to move in order to redress their citizenship status doesn't really do justice to the problem they encounter, because many of them were born and bred in Khartoum. They have built their lives there. For them to uproot and go to the South, the place where their parents were born and to which they otherwise may have no affiliation, is a very tall order.If there are refugees from the South because of communal violence, will they head to the north or are they more likely go to areas bordering the South? Currently, we have contingency plans in all nine countries neighbouring Sudan. However, in the context of the situation in the South itself, the more likely destinations are indeed the countries neighbouring South Sudan and that is Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda and then further to the west, the Central African Republic and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.If this ambiguity continues in the north regarding citizenship for South Sudanese, will they eventually fall under UNHCR's mandate? Will they be stateless? This is a complicated question; those Southerners who have been living in the north will not automatically become refugees because they would have to establish that they have the claim of persecution back in the South, which is not the case, so they will have to be treated on the premise of individual circumstances. Our concern for this group is indeed that they are at risk of becoming stateless. The fact that there is now an international border as of July 9 separating Sudan from South Sudan, means there will be a number of other internally displaced people (IDPs) who find themselves in a refugee-like situation. This concerns, for instance, IDPs from Darfur who have crossed into South Sudan. With the independence of the South, they will likely be considered as refugees.What is happening in the Blue Nile area? For the time being, we know that the area is very tense. The context is similar to the other areas, related to the discontinuation of the joint integrated units comprising military personnel from both the north and South. In addition, there's a lot of political tension and ethnic friction related to secession. So, it is in a way a similar situation to what prevailed earlier in Southern Kordofan and the UN is undertaking contingency planning to prepare for possible displacements.
